title: 103_hr364
content: The "Small Business Meat Producer and Marketer Protection Act of 1993" amends the Small Business Act by adding conditions for credit and reasonable rates. It also addresses loan program issues in the livestock and meat industry. The Congress recognizes that detrimental marketing conditions in industries involved in commerce of livestock and meat products impact the free and competitive environment, leading to unfair competition and obstruction of commerce. The policy of the Act is to regulate commerce to address these issues. The Act aims to regulate commerce to address detrimental marketing conditions in industries involved in livestock and meat products, ensuring fair competition and eliminating obstacles to commerce. It defines key terms such as "commerce," "livestock," and "meat food products." The Act defines key terms related to the livestock and meat industry, including livestock, meat food products, meatpacker, meat marketer, and person. The Act defines key terms related to the livestock and meat industry, including livestock, meat food products, meatpacker, meat marketer, and person. A "meatpacker or meat marketer engaged in commerce" refers to entities involved in the production, processing, manufacturing, or distribution of meat food products with annual sales of at least $250,000. Sec. 4 of the Act prohibits meatpackers from slaughtering more than a specified number of cattle, swine, or sheep per week if they were owned for over twenty days by the meatpacker or any person with significant ownership in the company. It is unlawful for meatpackers to offer for sale or purchase more than a specified number of live cattle, swine, or sheep per week if they were owned by the meatpacker or any person with significant ownership in the company. The law prohibits meatpackers from selling or buying more than a certain number of live cattle, swine, or sheep per week if they were owned by the meatpacker or any person with significant ownership in the company. The subsection applies to livestock owned or controlled by meatpackers or meat marketers, allowing them to trade commodity futures on designated markets. It is unlawful for meatpackers to contract for forward livestock delivery with the ability to select the delivery date beyond twenty consecutive calendar days. Violating these provisions is subject to penalties. The Act prohibits meatpackers from selecting livestock delivery dates beyond twenty consecutive calendar days. Violations can result in fines up to $50,000 or a specified amount per head of slaughtered animals. Corporate violations are also attributed to individual directors, officers, or agents involved. The Act prohibits meatpackers from selecting livestock delivery dates beyond twenty consecutive calendar days, with violations resulting in fines. Corporate violations are attributed to individual directors, officers, or agents. Violations of the Act are considered separate for each calendar week. This Act is considered an antitrust law. If any provision of the Act is held invalid, the remainder remains unaffected.
